text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Delegations from Estonia and Finland approved in Helsinki a draft agreement on visa-free travel. The deadlines for signing and the implementation of the proposals were left undecided.
- Central bank president Vahur Kraft dismissed in parliament yesterday the doubts of opposition Centre Party members of parliament about the central bank's actions.
- The government has been successful in checking illegal arms deals in Estonia and there is no legal vaccuum in that sphere anymore, Prime Minister Tiit Vaehi told parliament.

- Forged documents, proving proficiency in the Estonian language can be bought at markets for 500 kroons, officials from the language department discovered. Part of the process for Russian-speakers to be naturalised as an Estonian citizen is the need to know and prove they can speak the language.

- The education ministry asked for 50 million kroons but was promised only 35.5 million kroons in the 1997 budget for new technology, dubbed the "tiger leap" into the future by President Lennart Meri. Students of Tartu University say the computer project should be called "the lying tiger".
- A Latvian vessel was found trawling in Estonian waters on September 19, violating the recent sea border agreement.
- Estonia's leading heart surgeon Toomas Sulling said operating on Russian President Boris Yeltsin has been left too late and no great success can be expected.
- The re-election of Lennart Meri will ensure that investments to Estonia will continue, foreign experts said.
- IMF resident representative Basil Zavoico believes that inflation in Estonia in 1997 will remain at the current level or even grow whereas Vaehi's advisor Heido Vitsur believes inflation will fall.
